messages.content: What type of license is the GNU General Public License?
The GNU General Public License is a free, copyleft license for software and other kinds of works.
What is the purpose of the GNU General Public License?
The purpose of the GNU General Public License is to guarantee the freedom to share and change all versions of a program, ensuring it remains free software for all users.
What does 'free software' refer to in the context of the GNU General Public License?

In the context of the GNU General Public License, 'free software' refers to freedom, not price, and ensures the freedom to distribute copies of free software, receive source code, change the software, and use pieces of it in new free programs.
What are the responsibilities of a user who distributes copies of a program under the GNU General Public License?
Users who distribute copies of a program under the GNU General Public License must pass on the same freedoms they received, provide source code, and inform recipients of the license terms.
What does the GNU General Public License say about warranty and liability?
The GNU General Public License states that there is no warranty for free software and excludes liability for damages arising from the use or inability to use the program.
Can a user who received a program under the GNU General Public License modify and propagate the program?
Yes, a user who received a program under the GNU General Public License can modify and propagate the program as long as they comply with the terms of the license.
What is the difference between a 'covered work' and a 'modified version' under the GNU General Public License?
A 'covered work' refers to either the unmodified Program or a work based on the Program, while a 'modified version' refers to a work that has been modified or adapted from the original work.
What is human-parser-comfyui-node?
human-parser-comfyui-node is an out-of-box human parsing representation extractor that ranks 1st for all human parsing tracks in the third LIP challenge.
Which datasets are supported by human-parser-comfyui-node?
human-parser-comfyui-node supports three popular single person human parsing datasets: LIP, ATR, and Pascal-Person-Part.
What are the features of human-parser-comfyui-node?

The features of human-parser-comfyui-node include an out-of-box human parsing extractor for downstream applications, pretrained models on three popular datasets, training and inference code, and a simple yet effective extension on multi-person and video human parsing tasks.
How can I use human-parser-comfyui-node to extract human parsing representations from my own images?

To extract human parsing representations using human-parser-comfyui-node, put your images in the INPUT_PATH folder, download a pretrained model, and run the provided command with the appropriate dataset and checkpoint path. The output images will be saved in OUTPUT_PATH.
What is the purpose of the LIP dataset?

The LIP dataset is the largest single person human parsing dataset with over 50,000 images. It focuses more on complicated real scenarios and has 20 labels, including various clothing items and body parts.
How can I visualize the output images generated by human-parser-comfyui-node?
To better visualize the output images, human-parser-comfyui-node provides a palette with the output images. It is suggested to read the image using PIL.
How can I extend human-parser-comfyui-node for multiple human parsing?
To extend human-parser-comfyui-node for multiple human parsing, refer to the provided MultipleHumanParsing.md file for more details.
